captions.text:
When you think about touring in India, one
brand instantaneously pops into your head

-- Royal Enfield! And when you start thinking
about Royal Enfield, you start wondering about

why these bikes are so expensive even though
they don't feature the latest technology and

then you ponder some more when you think about
the massive cult following Royal Enfield enjoys,

not just in India, but across the globe. So
here we are today at PowerDrift, to review

their latest flagship model, the Thunderbird
500, in our bid to understand, what makes
Royal Enfield such a thumping success.

At first glance, the styling on the Thunderbird 500 did not appeal to me as much, but with
every km. I clocked thereafter, the bike really

started growing on me. The bike is Royal Enfield's
take on a modern day cruiser while still preserving

the charm of the good old thumpers. And I
think they have achieved that.

The first thing I noticed is the matt black
engine which I think looks a lot better than

the conventional aluminum finish as on the
other bikes. But the one feature that stood

out to me the most is the brawny new 20 litre
tank. I think I like it even more than the

new projector headlight assembly which looks
really good, but that is still my favourite.

Talking about the projector, the projector
along with the new LED tail light, they add

a conventional twist to the otherwise retro
feel of this bike. Even the new instrument

cluster is in tune with the overall design
and this is the first Royal Enfield which

has a hazard light and the button is positioned
between the tachometer and the speedometer.

Another interesting feature that I like on
this bike is the split seat assembly and then

the handlebar and the new exhaust complete
the design overhaul on the new Thunderbird.

The Thunderbird borrows its 499cc Twinspark
UCE engine from the Classic 500. So it belts out the same 27.2bhp of power and 41.3 Nm
of torque which is enough to propel the bike

to a top whack of 130kmph. It is at its thumping
best when you are riding or are cruising between

80-100kph.
Once past 3800rpm, the vibrations creep in

setting the footpegs abuzz. The gears don't
always slot in properly when upshifting with

the rear shifter. The braking performance
on the Thunderbird has improved as well thanks

to the 280mm front disc which comes with a
2-Piston caliper and it also comes shod the

240mm rear disc which comes with a single
piston caliper.

Handling and cruisers, they don't exactly
go hand-in-hand but I think the engineers

at Royal Enfield felt otherwise. And when
you ride this bike through a set of corners,

you feel that handling was perhaps the top
most priority when they decided to upgrade

the Thunderbird.
Beefier and stiffer 41 mm front forks, a shortened

wheelbase, an all new swingarm, new front
set footpegs and a redesigned handlebar, all

of these changes have transformed this bike
into one of the best handling thumpers yet.

It is rock solid even past 120kmph and leans
so convincingly into corners that I think

you will get addicted to setting the road
ablaze, everytime you enter a corner. And

the short turning radius and short wheelbase
make it darn easy to turn this motorcycle

and maneuver it even through traffic.
The small changes that RE have made to the

ergos have gone a long way in increasing the
comfort on this bike. The rider footpegs are

now more front set, the handlebar has been
redesigned and the well cushioned split seat

assembly and backrest have been tailored to
make long highway rides a pleasant affair

for the rider as well as the pillion. The
suspension is a little on the stiffer side

but it can still tackle broken roads reasonably
well.

So what's the verdict then, I think the Thunderbird
500 is undoubtedly one of the best cruisers

that Royal Enfield has produced yet. From
the touring perspective it checks all the

right boxes. It is really comfortable, the
projector headlamps work great for night rides,

the horn is nice and sharp and loud, the larger
fuel tank means you can cover more distance

and the fuel injection works great even on
cold winter mornings.

Some of the teething issues still exist. I
mean the gearbox is still fussy, the vibes

still make their present felt at high rpms
and the fuel guage, well it has a mind of

its own. But there is no denying the fact
that Royal Enfield have come of age with this

model and they are slowly but surely ironing
out the chinks in their armour. And so even

though this bike is going to be priced or
is priced 13000Rs. more expensive than the

Classic, I am convinced, the waiting for this
motorcycle is only going to increase as it

converts more fans and purists in its wake.
So here at PowerDrift, we can definitely feel
the thump.
